subdebateinfo.title: Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders: Meningococcal Disease
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2529)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Health and Aged Care, upon notice, on 5 April 2001:

quote.para: (1) In light of the fact that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders are four times more likely to develop meningococcal disease than other Australians, what steps are being taken to rectify this matter.

(2) What new policy developments are being implemented to ensure that Indigenous Australians receive the same level of medical care, and subsequently enjoy the same level of health conditions as other Australians.

(3) As meningococcal disease is closely linked with socio-economic conditions, is the Government implementing initiatives to ensure an increase in standards of the socio-economic conditions of Australia's Indigenous population.

(4) Does the Government have any active targets with regards to health standards amongst all of Australia's Indigenous communities; if so, to what degree is the Government succeeding in reaching these targets.

talker.name: Wooldridge, Dr Michael, MP
Dr Wooldridge
talker.role: Minister for Health and Aged Care

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) State and Territory Governments have developed specific prevention and treatment plans for their Indigenous populations based on the local epidemiology of meningococcal disease and access to health services. National data for comparison are currently not available because of low identification of Indigenous people in many areas. However, some studies do suggest that rates of meningitis are higher in Indigenous people. Communicable disease surveillance systems have been designed to collect data on the Indigenous status of persons diagnosed with meningococcal disease so that the burden of this disease in Indigenous Australians can be monitored and appropriate control and preventative action taken. My Department, through the Communicable Disease Network Australia, the Public Health Laboratory Network and the National Public Health Partnership, is nearing completion of a revision of national meningococcal disease guidelines. These new best practice guidelines contain specific information on the prevention and management of meningococcal disease in Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities. The revised guidelines will be made widely available to health care workers and the public once they have been finalised.

(2) The Government's key advisory body, the National Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Health Council is oversighting the development of a National Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Health Strategy to build on the existing 1989 National Aboriginal Health Strategy. This is a significant development that brings together all partners in working collaboratively to improve the health levels of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. Over the past five years a systematic planned approach to realising long-term goals in Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander health has been developed and implemented. Systemic achievements include: the formalisation of cooperative arrangements between parties through the Framework Agreements in each State and Territory; regional planning to identify needs, gaps and priorities; more primary health care services; improvements in the capacity of the primary health care system, through health workforce training, availability of strategies to address some of the most significant health issues and better use of technology. The Government's major focus in Indigenous health is on increasing the access of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people to comprehensive primary health care. Experience gained from the Aboriginal coordinated care trials combined with regional planning processes are now informing the rollout of the Primary Health Care Access Program, the Government's major initiative in this area. In addition, specific health issues are being targeted in areas such as sexual health, eye health, hearing health, chronic disease management, substance use, social and emotional wellbeing and immunisation.
(3) Refer to answer provided by DORATSIA to Question 2530.

(4) The Government's key indicator in Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander health is the same as that for all jurisdictions in line with the agreed set of National Performance Indicators. National Performance Indicator 1.1 is increasing life expectancy at birth and is for a 20 percent reduction in age standardised all causes mortality rate ratios over ten years. However it must be understood that changes in this indicator will be demonstrated in the longer term. In the shorter term there are many areas where individual programs are showing positive results. For example, the rate of infant deaths has dropped from over 20 times higher than the non-Aboriginal rate to now being around three to five times higher.
